text: RT @EnvAgencyYNE: 1/2 As part of #flood defence works in #York from Scarborough Bridge to the bottom of Marygate and  Museum Gardens there…

The @EnvAgency have become a useless toothless organisation.Plenty more pollution issues in the Uk going unresolved as EA won’t act.
This one is something different though, why normalise health harms? It makes no sense #stopthestink https://t.co/NrA0uTgEwa

@TeamBen_13 @ClareDinnisEA @pow_rebecca @EnvAgency @EnvAgency A breach is a breach , if it's management failures does that signal they aren't competent in running a landfill as per YOUR CRITERIA ?? You're equally as incompetent . #StopTheStink @StinkStopthe

text: @davemh72 @scottdegg @SianieRoo @ClareDinnisEA @JamesBevanEA @EnvAgency @DefraUKAir @DefraGovUK @JuliaBradbury The government depts are afraid of Red/Walleys‘  Barristers hence  residents have to suffer the menace.  We need a law firm to take on the Company to resolve and then ALL  Government Departments involved  for incompetence, failure to resolve and dereliction of duty.

@BenM_Anderson @EnvAgencyMids I think it's about current landfill capacity too. Large reduction in the number of landfills in the last decade. Not enough waste being processed by greener methods. Slow uptake on recycling. They're still heavily reliant on landfill. If they close the site, there is no Plan B.

And why no enforcement&no financial penalties @EnvAgency ?Breach after breach but no punishment/incentive to stop.They’re too busy dumping waste to finish your instructions anyway which you’re partially responsible for when you refused to curtail their waste ops #stopthestink https://t.co/9rw3vW5riw

@missyjosiejo @SianieRoo @EnvAgencyMids for @EnvAgency to grow a spine and use ALL of their powers , which may I remind them include permit revocation !

RT @EnvAgencyNW: Did you know that the proposed £56m #Rochdale & #Littleborough #flood scheme, which will protect 1000 properties & key inf…

@CavernamVenenum @EnvAgencyMids But surely the govt. could just step in and compulsory purchase order the land. I assume that is just considered too expensive (since they would then also have to pay for clean up, with or without a fine). With enough funding though, this can surely be fixed?

@CavernamVenenum @EnvAgencyMids My guess: cost + legal and admin barriers. I assume the EA could order an immediate halt to operations, but I doubt they could then appropriate the land to sort the problem out. It looks like for that, they'd need a prosecution: a long time: 7.4.5 https://t.co/N2YfZThtfm

urls.title: Environment Agency enforcement and sanctions policy
urls.description: We use some essential cookies to make this website work. We’d like to set additional cookies to understand how you use GOV.UK, remember your settings and improve government services. We also use cookies set by other sites to help us deliver content from their services. Where we have identified any third party copyright information you will need to obtain permission from the copyright holders concerned. This publication is available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/environment-agency-enforcement

urls.title: River Thames Conditions
urls.description: Welcome to the Environment Agency's online River Thames conditions update service which displays our current advice to river users. We display warning boards at our locks to inform river users of conditions that may make navigating difficult and dangerous. This page shows our current advice for each reach of the river between Cricklade and Teddington. We will update this information regularly when warning boards are being displayed at locks and as river conditions change. Upstream of St John's Lock No
